accessKeyActive.title: Active
accessKeyActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS IAM access key is not active based on the
`AWS > IAM > Access Key > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Access Key > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

accessKeyCmdb.title: CMDB
accessKeyCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM access key into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

accessKeyConfigured.title: Configured
accessKeyConfigured.description:
Maintain AWS > IAM > Access Key configuration

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

accessKeyDiscovery.title: Discovery
accessKeyDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS IAM access key resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

accessKeyUsage.title: Usage
accessKeyUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS IAM access key resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this user.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > IAM > Access Key > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > IAM > Access Key > Usage > Limit` policy.

groupApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS IAM group is not approved based on `AWS > IAM > Group > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

if Turbot > Permissions are  checked, and skippped if Turbot Permissions
are none or skip

roleDiscovery.title: Discovery
roleDiscovery.description:
Discover all AWS IAM role resources and add them to the CMDB.

The [Discovery](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/discovery) control is responsible for finding resources of a specific type. It periodically searches for new resources and saves them to the CMDB. Once discovered, resources are then responsible for tracking changes to themselves through the [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control.

roleAttachedPoliciesRequired.title: Required
roleAttachedPoliciesRequired.description: Determines whether AWS > IAM > Role Required policies are attached to the IAM role, as well as take the subsequent action to add the required policies. If set to "Enforce:Required > Items", required policies will be added to IAM Role.

roleTags.title: Tags
roleTags.description:
Take an action when an AWS IAM role tags is not updated based on the `AWS > IAM > Role > Tags > * policies`.

If the resource is not updated with the tags defined in `AWS > IAM > Role > Tags > Template`, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

rolePolicyTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
rolePolicyTrustedAccess.description:
Take an action when AWS IAM role policy is not trusted based on the
`AWS > IAM > Role > Policy > Trusted Access > *` policies.

The Trusted Access control evaluates the role policy against the list of allowed
members in each of the Trusted Access sub-policies (Trusted Access > Accounts,
Trusted Access > Services etc.), this control raises an alarm and takes the
defined enforcement action.

The account that owns the role will always be trusted, even if its account ID is
not included in the Trusted Accounts policy.

If set to `Enforce: Revoke untrusted access`, access to non-trusted
members will be removed.

trustRelationshipStatementsApproved.title: Approved [Deprecated]
trustRelationshipStatementsApproved.description:
Configure Role trust relationship policy statements checking. This control defines whether role trust policy statements
are approved, as well as the subsequent action to take on unapproved statements. Rules for all `Approved`
policies will be compiled in `Approved > Compiled Rules` and then evaluated.

If set to `Enforce: Delete unapproved`, any unapproved principal will be
revoked from the role trust policy.

**Note:** This control has been deprecated in v5.8.0 and will be removed in v6.0.0. It has been replaced by the `AWS > IAM > Role > Policy > Trusted Access` control.

roleUsage.title: Usage
roleUsage.description:
The Usage control determines whether the number of AWS IAM role resources exceeds the configured usage limit for this account.

You can configure the behavior of this control with the  `AWS > IAM > Role > Usage` policy, and set the limit with the `AWS > IAM > Role > Usage > Limit` policy.

userActive.title: Active
userActive.description:
Take an action when an AWS IAM user is not active based on the
`AWS > IAM > User > Active > *` policies.

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > User > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.

Note the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

userApproved.title: Approved
userApproved.description:
Take an action when an AWS IAM user is not approved based on `AWS > IAM > User > Approved > * policies`.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

precheck.reason: CMDB control is in TBD state

userPolicyAttachmentsApproved.title: Approved
userPolicyAttachmentsApproved.description:
Configure AWS IAM user policies binding `Approved` checking. This policy
defines whether to verify the IAM user attached policies are approved
(per `Approved > Compiled Rules`), as well as the subsequent action to
take on unapproved items.
If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved attached policy
will be removed.

userBoundary.title: Boundary
userBoundary.description:
Configure which boundary policy to apply to the IAM user.
This must be the name of an existing AWS IAM Boundary policy.

AWS Boundary Policies are used to enforce Turbot Guardrails for
enabling/disabling API Services and Regions.

If set to `Check or Enforce per AWS > Turbot > Permissions` (the default),
the boundary will be enforced if Turbot > Permissions are enforced, checked
if Turbot > Permissions are  checked, and skippped if Turbot Permissions
are none or skip

userCmdb.title: CMDB
userCmdb.description:
Record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM user into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

accessKeyActive.title: Active
accessKeyActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM access key, based on the `AWS > IAM > Access Key > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Access Key > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days

is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

accessKeyActiveStatus.title: Status
accessKeyActiveStatus.description:
The policy allows you to
check which status determines if the AWS IAM access key is active.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the

sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

The policy values for AWS IAM access key are deprecated and replaced by new values.
The deprecated values will be removed in next major version.

| Deprecated Values                   | Current Values                         |
|-------------------------------------|----------------------------------------|
| Active if status is active         | Active if $.Status is active        |
| Force active if status is active   | Force active if $.Status is active  |

enum: Force active if status is active

accessKeyCmdb.title: CMDB
accessKeyCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM access key into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

accountPasswordPolicySettings.title: Settings
accountPasswordPolicySettings.description: Check if the IAM account password policy is in sync with the account password settings policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsAllowUsersT.title: Allow Users to Change
accountPasswordPolicySettingsAllowUsersT.description:
You can permit all IAM users in your account to use the IAM console to change their own passwords, as described in [Permitting IAM users to change their own passwords](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_enable-user-change.html).

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsHardExpiry.title: Hard Expiry
accountPasswordPolicySettingsHardExpiry.description:
You can prevent IAM users from choosing a new password after their current password has expired. For example, a password policy can specify a password expiration period. If an IAM user fails to choose a new password before the expiration period ends, the IAM user cannot set a new password. In that case, the IAM user must request a password reset from an account administrator in order to regain access to the AWS Management Console. You can also leave this check box cleared. If an IAM user allows his or her password to expire, the user in this scenario is required to set a new password before accessing the AWS Management Console.

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsMaxAge.title: Max Age
accountPasswordPolicySettingsMaxAge.description:
You can set IAM user passwords to be valid for only the specified number of days. You specify the number of days that passwords remain valid after they are set. For example, when you enable password expiration and set the password expiration period to 90 days, an IAM user can use a password for up to 90 days. After 90 days, the password expires and the IAM user must set a new password before accessing the AWS Management Console. You can choose a password expiration period between 1 and 1095 days, inclusive.

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsMinimumLeng.title: Minimum Length
accountPasswordPolicySettingsMinimumLeng.description:
You can specify the minimum number of characters allowed in an IAM user password. You can type any number from 6 to 128.

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsReusePreven.title: Reuse Prevention
accountPasswordPolicySettingsReusePreven.description:
You can prevent IAM users from reusing a specified number of previous passwords. You can set the number of previous passwords from 1 to 24, inclusive.

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireLowe.title: Require Lowercase Characters
accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireLowe.description:
You can require that IAM user passwords contain at least one lowercase character from the ISO basic Latin alphabet (a to z).

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireNumb.title: Require Numbers
accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireNumb.description:
You can require that IAM user passwords contain at least one numeric character (0 to 9).

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireSymb.title: Require Symbols
accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireSymb.description:
You can require that IAM user passwords contain at least one of the following nonalphanumeric characters:
`! @ # $ % ^ & * ( ) _ + - = [ ] { } | '`

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireUppe.title: Require Uppercase Characters
accountPasswordPolicySettingsRequireUppe.description:
You can require that IAM user passwords contain at least one uppercase character from the ISO basic Latin alphabet (A to Z).

Refer to [Setting an account password policy for IAM users](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_credentials_passwords_account-policy.html) for more information on account password policies.

accountSummaryCmdb.title: CMDB
accountSummaryCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM account summary into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

credentialReportCmdb.title: CMDB
credentialReportCmdb.description: Record and synchronize details of AWS IAM credential report into the CMDB.

groupActive.title: Active
groupActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM group, based on the `AWS > IAM > Group > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Group > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

groupActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
groupActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS IAM group
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

groupActiveAge.title: Age
groupActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS IAM group
is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

groupActiveBudget.title: Budget
groupActiveBudget.description:
The impact of the budget state on the active control. This policy allows you to force
groups to inactive based on the current budget state, as reflected in
`AWS > Account > Budget > State`

The Active control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated compliance
environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms that are difficult
and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings automated, well-defined
control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Group > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force inactive if Budget > State is Over or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Force inactive if Budget > State is Shutdown

groupApproved.title: Approved
groupApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM group is not approved based on `AWS > IAM > Group > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

groupApprovedTurbot.title: Turbot
groupApprovedTurbot.description: Determine whether IAM Policies that are defined and configured by Turbot (for example, from the Permissions stack or the Service Roles stack) will always be approved.

groupApprovedUsage.title: Usage
groupApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS IAM group is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS IAM group is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > IAM > Group > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

groupApprovedBudget.title: Budget
groupApprovedBudget.description:
The policy allows you to set groups to unapproved based on the current budget state, as reflected in `AWS > Account > Budget > State`

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS IAM group is not matched by the approved list, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > IAM > Group > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

enum: Unapproved if Budget > State is Over or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Critical or higher
Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown
example: Unapproved if Budget > State is Shutdown

groupPolicyAttachmentsApproved.title: Approved
groupPolicyAttachmentsApproved.description:
Configure AWS IAM group policy attachments `Approved` checking. This policy
defines whether to verify the IAM group attached policies are approved
(per `Approved > Compiled Rules`), as well as the subsequent action to
take on unapproved items.
If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved attached policy
will be removed.

groupPolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.title: Rules
groupPolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.description:
An [Object Control List (OCL)](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/reference/ocl) with a list of filter rules
to approve or reject policies.
Note that the Approved control does not operate directly from this policy,
but from the `Approved > Compiled Rules`.  The rules are processed in order,
and any built-in Turbot rules will appear first in the list of compiled rules.

groupPolicyAttachmentsApprovedCompiledRu.title: Compiled Rules
groupPolicyAttachmentsApprovedCompiledRu.description:
A read-only [Object Control List (OCL)](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/reference/ocl) to add or
remove IAM Policy from a IAM group.
This policy is generated by Turbot.

groupCmdb.title: CMDB
groupCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM group into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

groupConfigured.title: Configured
groupConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

groupConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

groupConfiguredPrecedence.description:

A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.

groupPolicyRequired.title: Required
groupPolicyRequired.description:
Configure whether required policies should be attached to a group.
If set to Enforce,  policies in Required > Items will be attached to the group.

groupPolicyRequiredItems.title: Items
groupPolicyRequiredItems.description: A list of IAM policies that must be attached to a group.

groupPolicyRequiredCompiledItems.title: Compiled Items
groupPolicyRequiredCompiledItems.description:
A list of IAM policies that must be attached to a group.

This is a read-only policy that is generated by Turbot

groupUsage.title: Usage
groupUsage.description:
Configure the number of AWS IAM groups that can be used for this account and the current consumption against the limit.

You can configure the behavior of the control with this  `AWS > IAM > Group > Usage` policy.

groupUsageLimit.title: Limit
groupUsageLimit.description: Maximum number of items that can be created for this account.

iamCustomEventPatterns.title: @turbot/aws-iam
iamCustomEventPatterns.description:
The CloudWatch Events event pattern used by the AWS IAM module to specify
which events to forward to the Turbot Event Handlers.

permissions.title: Permissions
permissions.description:
This policy determines the permission mode used by Turbot. There are 3 possible configurations:

None: Turbot will not manage any AWS IAM permissions. This setting is for organizations that want to maintain complete control over AWS IAM.

Policy-Only Mode: Turbot policies are created in AWS IAM, but no management of roles or users will occur. This option helps automate policy creation across a wide number of accounts while keeping control in the hands of the organization.

Role Mode: Turbot will create policies and roles within the AWS account. This allows administrators to assign AWS permissions in Turbot. Users federate into AWS and will assume the role that is assigned to their profile in Turbot.

**Note**: Support for policy values Enforce: User Mode and Check: User Mode has been temporarily withdrawn from AWS > Turbot > Permissions policy. Please note that the changes are backward compatible and will not affect any previous policy settings.

permissionsSuperuserBoundary.title: Superuser Boundary
permissionsSuperuserBoundary.description:
Configure whether Turbot should apply the Boundary
Policy to AWS/Superuser.

By default, the boundary is applied to all users,
however you can disable the boundary for superusers
by setting this policy to `No Boundary`

permissionsCustomLevelsAccount.title: Custom Levels [Account]
permissionsCustomLevelsAccount.description: An ordered list of custom levels used to customize Turbot's permissions. Levels  in this policy will appear in the Turbot console as grantable to Turbot users as AWS/Role/{role name}.  When granted access, Turbot will allow the user to assume the associated IAM role. Note that the IAM roles must already exist in the AWS Account, and turbot must have the ability to assume the roles.

permissionsLevelsDefault.title: Levels [Default]
permissionsLevelsDefault.description: Define the permissions levels that can be used to grant access to an AWS account. Permissions levels defined will appear in the UI to assign access to Turbot users. This policy provides a default for Permissions > Levels in each service, however you can explicitly override the setting for each service if desired

permissionsLevels.title: Levels
permissionsLevels.description: Define the permissions levels that can be used to grant access to an AWS account.  Permissions levels defined will appear in the UI to assign access to Turbot users.

permissionsLevelsModifiers.title: Modifiers
permissionsLevelsModifiers.description: A map of AWS API to Turbot Permission Level used to customize Turbot's standard permissions. You can add, remove or redefine the mapping of AWS API operations to Turbot permissions levels here. Note: Modifiers are cumulative - if you add a permission to the Metadata level, it is also added to ReadOnly, Operator and Admin. Modifier policies set here apply ONLY to the AWS level

permissionsLockdownApiBoundary.title: API Boundary
permissionsLockdownApiBoundary.description:
A list of APIs that should be allowed in the Turbot
boundary policy.

This is represented as a list of apis and their
scope (regional or global).

For example:

  ```
  - api: 's3:*'
    regionScope: regional
  - api: 'iam:*'
    regionScope: global
  ```

**Note**: That APIs can be enabled or disabled via the
relevant `AWS > {Service} > API Enabled` policies.
An API will be allowed in the boundary if it is
EITHER enabled via `AWS > {Service} > API Enabled`
OR added to the `AWS > Turbot > Permissions >
Lockdown > API Boundary` policy.

permissionsLockdownRegionBoundary.title: Region Boundary
permissionsLockdownRegionBoundary.description:
Define a list of regions to which API calls can be made. Any API to any region that does not appear in this list will be explicitly denied. The '*' wildcard may be used in these values.

Note that this policy disables the region for ALL users and roles,
and Turbot will have no access to any regions that do not appear in
the list.

Global services (such as IAM) are not subject to the Region Boundary

permissionsLockdownRegions.title: Regions
permissionsLockdownRegions.description: Define a list of regions to which API calls can be made. Any API to any region that does not appear in this list will be explicitly denied. The '*' wildcard may be used in these values.
permissionsLockdownRegions.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.regions.value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.regions.value %}- '{{ item }}'{{ '
' }}{% endfor %}

iamTurbot.title: Turbot
iamTurbot.description: Configures Turbot IAM Users, Groups, Roles, and Policies, per AWS > Permissions.

turbotNamePrefixDefault.title: Name Prefix [Default]
turbotNamePrefixDefault.description: Provides a default prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM objects.  This policy can be referenced other policies (User > Name Prefix, Role > Name Prefix, Group > Name Prefix, Policy > Name Prefix) to set a single, consistent default

turbotTagsDefault.title: Tags Default
turbotTagsDefault.description: Provides a default prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM objects.  This policy can be referenced other policies (User > Name Prefix, Role > Name Prefix, Group > Name Prefix, Policy > Name Prefix) to set a single, consistent default

turbotNamePathDefault.title: Name Path [Default]
turbotNamePathDefault.description: Provides a default value to be used in resource path names for standard Turbot IAM objects.  The path should start and end with a slash (/) This policy can be referenced other policies (User > Name Path, Role > Name Path, Groups > Name Path, Policy > Name Path) to set a single, consistent default

turbotUser.title: User
turbotUser.description: Configures Turbot IAM Users, depending on AWS > Permissions.

turbotUserNamePrefix.title: Name Prefix
turbotUserNamePrefix.description: A prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM Users.

turbotUserNamePath.title: Name Path
turbotUserNamePath.description: The value to be used in resource path names for standard Turbot IAM Users. The path should start and end with a slash (/).

turbotUserTags.title: Tags
turbotUserTags.description: Ensure AWS IAM Role tags for Turbot role include tags defined in User Tags.

turbotGroup.title: Group
turbotGroup.description: Configures Turbot IAM Groups, depending on AWS > Permissions.

turbotGroupNamePrefix.title: Name Prefix
turbotGroupNamePrefix.description: A prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM Groups.

turbotGroupNamePath.title: Name Path
turbotGroupNamePath.description: The value to be used in resource path names for standard Turbot IAM Groups. The path should start and end with a slash (/).

turbotRole.title: Role
turbotRole.description: Configures Turbot IAM Roles, depending on AWS > Permissions.

turbotRoleNamePrefix.title: Name Prefix
turbotRoleNamePrefix.description: A prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM Roles.

turbotRoleNamePath.title: Name Path
turbotRoleNamePath.description: The value to be used in resource path names for standard Turbot IAM Roles. The path should start and end with a slash (/).

turbotRoleTags.title: Tags
turbotRoleTags.description: Ensure AWS IAM Role tags for Turbot role include tags defined in Role Tags.

turbotPolicy.title: Policy
turbotPolicy.description: Configures Turbot IAM Policies, depending on AWS > Permissions.

turbotPolicyNamePrefix.title: Name Prefix
turbotPolicyNamePrefix.description: A prefix to be used in resource names for standard Turbot IAM Policies.

turbotPolicyNamePath.title: Name Path
turbotPolicyNamePath.description: The value to be used in resource path names for standard Turbot IAM Policies. The path should start and end with a slash (/).

iamPermissionsCompiledServicePermissions.title: Service Permissions
iamPermissionsCompiledServicePermissions.description: A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a single list of ALL permissions for all services that is used as input to the control that manages the IAM stack.

iamPermissionsCompiledAccountPermissions.title: Account Permissions
iamPermissionsCompiledAccountPermissions.description: A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a single list of ALL permissions for all provider level permissions (AWS/Admin, AWS/Operator, etc) that is used as input to the control that manages the IAM stack

turbotPermissionsCompiledLevels.title: AWS [Turbot]
turbotPermissionsCompiledLevels.description: A list of AWS permissions that Turbot may use to grant permissions on folders that have aws accounts as children.

turbotPermissionsCompiledLevelsAws.title: AWS
turbotPermissionsCompiledLevelsAws.description: A list of AWS permissions that Turbot may use to grant permissions on an account.

iamPermissionsCompiledLevels.title: Levels
iamPermissionsCompiledLevels.description: A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a single list of ALL permissions levels for all services that is used as input to the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

iamPermissionsCompiledLockdownStatements.title: Lockdown Statements
iamPermissionsCompiledLockdownStatements.description: A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a single list of ALL lockdown policy statements for all services that is used as input to the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

iamPermissionsCompiledAllowStatements.title: Allow Statements
iamPermissionsCompiledAllowStatements.description: A calculated policy that Turbot uses to create a compiled list of ALL custom "Allow" policy statements for AWS API Gateway that is used as input to the stack that manages the Turbot IAM permissions objects.

iamTurbotSource.title: Source
iamTurbotSource.description: A HCL format configuration template to create Turbot permissions policies.

accountPermissionsLockdownBudget.title: Budget
accountPermissionsLockdownBudget.description:
Configure lockdown policies to restrict APIs based on the
budget state (when the current spend exceeds a defined threshold).

enum: Restrict APIs per `Lockdown > Budget > Restricted APIs`

accountPermissionsLockdownBudgetRestrict.title: Restricted APIs
accountPermissionsLockdownBudgetRestrict.description:
A yaml object that contains a list of APIs that should
be restricted when the budget reaches a specific state.

For example, to restrict users from running and starting
new ec2 instances, starting RDS databases, or creating
Redshift clusters when the budget state is Critical or
higher, enter:

```
Critical:
    - ec2:RunInstance
    - ec2:StartInstance
    - rds:StartDB*
    - redshift:createcluster
```

iamApiEnabled.title: API Enabled
iamApiEnabled.description:
Configure whether the AWS S3 API is enabled.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

iamPermissions.title: Permissions
iamPermissions.description:
Configure whether permissions policies are in effect for AWS IAM. This setting does
not affect account level permissions (AWS/Admin, AWS/Owner, etc).

**Note:** The behavior of this policy depends on the value of `AWS > Permissions`.

enum: Enabled if AWS > IAM > Enabled & AWS > IAM > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > IAM > Enabled & AWS > IAM > API Enabled

iamPermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.title: API Boundary
iamPermissionsLockdownApiBoundary.description:
Configure whether the AWS IAM API is enabled for all
users and roles in turbot-managed boundary policies.

**Note:** Disabling the service disables the API for ALL users
and roles, and Turbot will have no access to the API.

enum: Enabled if AWS > IAM > API Enabled
example: Enabled if AWS > IAM > API Enabled
schema.default: Enabled if AWS > IAM > API Enabled

iamPermissionsLevels.title: Levels
iamPermissionsLevels.description:
Define the permissions levels that can be used to grant access to an AWS account.
Permissions levels defined will appear in the UI to assign access to Turbot users.
This policy provides a default for `Permissions > Levels` in each service,
however you can explicitly override the setting for each service if desired
iamPermissionsLevels.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.availableLevels.items[0].value | length == 0 %} [] {% endif %}{% for item in $.availableLevels.items[0].value %}- {{ item }}
{% endfor %}

iamPermissionsLevelsModifiers.title: Modifiers
iamPermissionsLevelsModifiers.description:
A map of AWS API to Turbot Permission Level used to customize Turbot's standard permissions.
You can add, remove or redefine the mapping of AWS API operations to Turbot permissions levels here.

**Note:** Modifiers are cumulative - if you add a permission to the Metadata level, it is also
added to ReadOnly, Operator and Admin. Modifier policies set here apply ONLY to the AWS level"

```
example:
  - "glacier:createvault": admin
  - "glacier:ListVaults": metadata
  - "s3:DeleteBucket": none
```

iamPermissionsLevelsServiceUserAdministr.title: Service User Administration
iamPermissionsLevelsServiceUserAdministr.description: Determines which Turbot permissions level can manage Service User Administration.

iamPermissionsLevelsServiceUserAccessKey.title: Service User Access Key Administration

iamStack.title: Stack
iamStack.description:
Configure a custom stack on AWS, per the custom `Stack > Source`.

A Turbot `Stack` is a set of resources configured by Turbot, as specified
via Terraform source.  Stacks are responsible for the creation and deletion
of multiple resources. Once created, stack resources are responsible for
configuring themselves from the stack source via their `Configured` control.

iamStackSource.title: Source
iamStackSource.description:
The Terraform HCL source used to configure this stack.

A Turbot `Stack` is a set of resources configured by Turbot, as specified
via Terraform source.  Stacks are responsible for the creation and deletion
of multiple resources. Once created, stack resources are responsible for
configuring themselves from the stack source via their `Configured` control.

iamStackVariables.description:

Turbot will use to run this stack.

A Turbot `Stack` is a set of resources configured by Turbot,

iamTagsTemplate.title: Tags Template [Default]
iamTagsTemplate.description:
A template used to generate the keys and values for AWS IAM resources.

By default, all IAM resource Tags > Template policies will use this value.
iamTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

iamPolicyTrustedAccounts.title: Trusted Accounts [Default]
iamPolicyTrustedAccounts.description:
List of AWS Accounts that are trusted for access in the AWS IAM policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "account" are allowed
to be granted access. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

```
example:
  - "013122550996"
  - "560741234067"
```

**Note**: Setting the policy to `Empty` array will remove all accounts.
iamPolicyTrustedAccounts.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.trustedAccounts.value | length == 0 %}[]{% else %}{% for item in $.trustedAccounts.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}{% endif %}

iamPolicyTrustedServices.title: Trusted Services [Default]
iamPolicyTrustedServices.description:
List of AWS Services that are trusted for access in the AWS IAM policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "service" are allowed
to be granted access. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

```
example:
  - "sns.amazonaws.com"
  - "ec2.amazonaws.com"
```

**Note**: Setting the policy to `Empty` array will remove all services.
iamPolicyTrustedServices.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.trustedServices.value | length == 0 %}[]{% else %}{% for item in $.trustedServices.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}{% endif %}

iamPolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.title: Trusted Identity Providers [Default]
iamPolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.description:
List of AWS Identity Providers that are trusted for access in the AWS IAM policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "identity provider" are allowed
to be granted access. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

```
example:
  - "www.amazon.com"
  - "graph.facebook.com"
```

**Note**: Setting the policy to `Empty` array will remove all identity providers.
iamPolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.trustedIdentityProviders.value | length == 0 %}[]{% else %}{% for item in $.trustedIdentityProviders.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}{% endif %}

iamPolicyTrustedOrganizations.title: Trusted Organizations [Default]
iamPolicyTrustedOrganizations.description:
List of AWS Organizations that are trusted for access in the AWS IAM policy.

This policy is used by the Trusted Access
control to determine which members of type "organization" are allowed
to be granted access. You may use the '*' and '?' wildcard characters.

```
example:
  - "o-333333333"
  - "o-c3a5y4wd52"
```

**Note**: `Trusted Access > Organization Restrictions` are ONLY
applied to AWS principals.  Services and Federated principals do
NOT contain the `aws:PrincipalOrgId` condition key, and thus
cannot be validated against the Organization.

Setting the policy to `Empty` array will remove all organizations.
iamPolicyTrustedOrganizations.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.trustedOrganizations.value | length == 0 %}[]{% else %}{% for item in $.trustedOrganizations.value %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}{% endif %}

iamPolicyActive.title: Active
iamPolicyActive.description:
Configure the behavior of the
[Active](https://turbot.cloud/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) control
for the AWS IAM policy, based on the `AWS > IAM > Policy > Active > *` policies.

The [Active](https://turbot.cloud/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Policy > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active. Note the contrast with Approved, where if the
resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

iamPolicyActiveAge.title: Age
iamPolicyActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS IAM policy is no longer considered active. If a create time
is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.cloud/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Policy > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active. Note the contrast with Approved, where if the
resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

iamPolicyActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
iamPolicyActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS IAM policy was last modified before it is considered
inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.cloud/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Policy > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active. Note the contrast with Approved, where if the
resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

iamPolicyApproved.title: Approved
iamPolicyApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM policy is not approved based on AWS > IAM > Policy > Approved > * policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

iamPolicyApprovedTurbot.title: Turbot
iamPolicyApprovedTurbot.description: Determine whether IAM Policies that are defined and configured by Turbot (for example, from the Permissions stack or the Service Roles stack) will always be approved.

iamPolicyApprovedUsage.title: Usage
iamPolicyApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS IAM policy is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS IAM policy is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the AWS > IAM > Policy > Approved policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

iamPolicyCmdb.title: CMDB
iamPolicyCmdb.description: Record and synchronize details for AWS IAM policy(s) into the CMDB.

iamPolicyConfigured.title: Configured
iamPolicyConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

iamPolicyConfiguredSource.title: Source
iamPolicyConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

iamPolicyConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
iamPolicyConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
iamPolicyConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

statementsApproved.title: Approved
statementsApproved.description:
Configure IAM Policy Statements checking. This policy defines whether to verify the
policy statements are approved, as well as the subsequent action to take on unapproved
statements.

Rules for all Approved policies will be compiled in Approved > Compiled Rules
and then evaluated. If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved statements
will be removed from the policy.

statementsApprovedRules.title: Rules
statementsApprovedRules.description:
An Object Control List (OCL) with a list of filter rules to approve or reject IAM policy statements. Note that the Approved control does not operate directly from this policy, but from the Approved > Compiled Rules. The rules are processed in order, and any built-in Turbot rules will appear first in the list of compiled rules.
This is the last statement, so all unmatched items will be (approved/rejected) by this statement.

_Note_: Removing APPROVE * will reject all the unmatched rules.

statementsApprovedTurbot.title: Turbot
statementsApprovedTurbot.description: If Enabled, All IAM Policy statements for policies that are defined and configured by Turbot (for example, from the permissions stack of the Service Roles stack) will be approved.

statementsApprovedAdminAccess.title: Administrator Access
statementsApprovedAdminAccess.description: If set to "Disabled", IAM Policy statements that allow any action ('*') on any resource ('*') will be unapproved.

statementsApprovedCompiledRules.title: Compiled Rules
statementsApprovedCompiledRules.description: A read-only Object Control List (OCL) to approved or reject policy statements for an IAM policy.  This policy is generated by Turbot based on the "Approved > *" policies.

mfaVirtualActive.description: Check if the AWS IAM Mfavirtual is active based on AWS > IAM > Mfavirtual > Active > * policies.

roleActiveAge.title: Age
roleActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS IAM role
is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > Role > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,

**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

roleApproved.title: Approved
roleApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM role is not approved based on `AWS > IAM > Role > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

roleApprovedUsage.title: Usage
roleApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS IAM role is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS IAM role is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > IAM > Role > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

roleApprovedTurbot.title: Turbot
roleApprovedTurbot.description: Determine whether IAM Policies that are defined and configured by Turbot (for example, from the Permissions stack or the Service Roles stack) will always be approved.

rolePolicyAttachmentsApproved.title: Approved
rolePolicyAttachmentsApproved.description:
Configure AWS IAM role policy attachments `Approved` checking. This policy
defines whether to verify the IAM role attached policies are approved
(per `Approved > Compiled Rules`), as well as the subsequent action to
take on unapproved items.
If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved attached policy
will be removed.

rolePolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.title: Rules
rolePolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.description:
An Object Control List (OCL) with a list of filter rules
to approve or reject policies.
Note that the Approved control does not operate directly from this policy,
but from the `Approved > Compiled Rules`.  The rules are processed in order,
and any built-in Turbot rules will appear first in the list of compiled rules.

rolePolicyAttachmentsApprovedCompiledRul.title: Compiled Rules
rolePolicyAttachmentsApprovedCompiledRul.description:
A read-only Object Control List (OCL) to add or
remove IAM Policy from a IAM role.
This policy is generated by Turbot.

roleBoundary.title: Boundary
roleBoundary.description:
Configure which boundary policy to apply to the IAM role .
This must be the name of an existing AWS IAM Boundary policy.
AWS Boundary Policies are used to enforce Turbot Guardrails for
enabling/disabling API Services and Regions.

If set to `Check or Enforce per AWS > Turbot > Permissions`,
the boundary will be enforced if Turbot > Permissions are enforced, checked
if Turbot > Permissions are  checked, and skipped if Turbot Permissions
are none or skip

enum: Check or Enforce per `AWS > Turbot > Permissions`

roleBoundaryPolicy.title: Policy
roleBoundaryPolicy.description:
Configure which boundary policy to apply to the IAM role.
This must be the name of an existing AWS IAM Boundary policy.
AWS Boundary Policies are used to enforce Turbot Guardrails for
enabling/disabling API Services and Regions.

roleCmdb.title: CMDB
roleCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM role into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

roleConfigured.title: Configured
roleConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)

roleConfiguredSource.title: Source
roleConfiguredSource.description: A HCL or JSON format Terraform configuration source used to configure this resource

roleConfiguredPrecedence.title: Claim Precedence
roleConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
roleConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

rolePolicyRequired.title: Required
rolePolicyRequired.description:
Configure whether required policies should be attached to a role.
If set to Enforce,  policies in Required > Items will be attached to the role.

rolePolicyRequiredLockdown.title: Turbot Lockdown
rolePolicyRequiredLockdown.description: Configure whether Role has Turbot Lockdown Policies attached.

rolePolicyRequiredItems.title: Items
rolePolicyRequiredItems.description: A list of IAM policies that must be attached to a role.

rolePolicyRequiredCompiledItems.title: Compiled Items
rolePolicyRequiredCompiledItems.description:
A list of IAM policies that must be attached to a role.
This is a read-only policy that is generated by Turbot

roleTags.title: Tags
roleTags.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM role tags are not updated based on the `AWS > IAM > Role > Tags > *` policies.

The control ensure AWS IAM role tags include tags defined in `AWS > IAM > Role > Tags > Template`.

Tags not defined in Role Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.

roleTagsTemplate.title: Template
roleTagsTemplate.description:
The template is used to generate the keys and values for AWS IAM role.

Tags not defined in Role Tags Template will not be modified or deleted. Setting a tag value to `undefined` will result in the tag being deleted.

See [Tags](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/tagging) for more information.
roleTagsTemplate.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultTags.value | length == 0 %} [] {%- elif $.defaultTags.value != undefined %}{{ $.defaultTags.value | dump | safe }}{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultTags.value %}- {{ item }}{% endfor %}{% endif %}

rolePolicyTrustedAccess.title: Trusted Access
rolePolicyTrustedAccess.description:
Take an action when AWS IAM role policy is not trusted based on the
`AWS > IAM > Role > Policy > Trusted Access > *` policies.

The Trusted Access control evaluates the role policy against the list of allowed
members in each of the Trusted Access sub-policies (Trusted Access > Accounts,
Trusted Access > Services etc.), this control raises an alarm and takes the
defined enforcement action.

The account that owns the role will always be trusted, even if its account ID is
not included in the Trusted Accounts policy.

If set to `Enforce: Revoke untrusted access`, access to non-trusted
members will be removed.

rolePolicyTrustedAccounts.title: Accounts
rolePolicyTrustedAccounts.description:
List of AWS Account IDs that are trusted for cross-account access in the
AWS IAM role policy.

Note that `Trusted Access > Accounts` and `Trusted Access >
Organizations` are evaluated independently. To have access, an AWS
principal must be allowed in `Trusted Access > Accounts` AND be a
member of an Organization that is allowed in `Trusted Access >
Organizations`.

```
example:
  - "123456789012"
```
**Note**: Setting the policy to an `Empty` array will remove all accounts.
rolePolicyTrustedAccounts.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.accounts | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.accounts %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rolePolicyTrustedServices.title: Services
rolePolicyTrustedServices.description:
List of AWS Services that are trusted for access in the AWS IAM role policy.

```
example:
  - sns.amazonaws.com
  - ec2.amazonaws.com
```

**Note**: Setting the policy to an `Empty` array will remove all services.
rolePolicyTrustedServices.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.services | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.services %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rolePolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.title: Identity Providers
rolePolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.description:
List of Identity Providers that are trusted for cross-account access in the
AWS IAM role policy.

```
example:
  - www.google.com
  - www.facebook.com
```
**Note**: Setting the policy to an `Empty` array will remove all identity providers.
rolePolicyTrustedIdentityProviders.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.identityProviders | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.identityProviders %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

rolePolicyTrustedOrganizations.title: Organization Restrictions
rolePolicyTrustedOrganizations.description:
List of AWS Organization IDs that are trusted for cross-account access in
the AWS IAM role policy, or '*' to skip the Organization Restriction.

Note that `Trusted Access > Accounts` and `Trusted Access >
Organizations` are evaluated independently. To have access, an AWS
principal must be allowed in `Trusted Access > Accounts` AND be a
member of an Organization that is allowed in `Trusted Access >
Organizations`.

**Note**: `Trusted Access > Organization Restrictions` are ONLY
applied to AWS principals.  Services and Federated principals do
NOT contain the `aws:PrincipalOrgId` condition key, and thus
cannot be validated against the Organization.

```
example:
  - "o-333333333"
  - "o-c3a5y4wd52"
```
rolePolicyTrustedOrganizations.defaultTemplate:
{% if $.organizations | length == 0 %}[]{% endif %}{% for item in $.organizations %}- '{{ item }}'
{% endfor %}

userActive.title: Active
userActive.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM user, based on the `AWS > IAM > User > Active > *` policies.

The control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not,
has the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > User > Active > *`), raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement
action. Each Active sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive
or skipped. Generally, if the resource appears to be Active for any reason
it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved for any reason it will be considered
Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Enforce: Delete inactive with 1 day warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 3 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 7 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 14 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 30 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 60 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 90 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 180 days warning
Enforce: Delete inactive with 365 days warning

userActiveLastModified.title: Last Modified
userActiveLastModified.description:
The number of days since the AWS IAM user
was last modified before it is considered inactive.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > User > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

enum: Force active if last modified <= 1 day
Force active if last modified <= 3 days
Force active if last modified <= 7 days
Force active if last modified <= 14 days
Force active if last modified <= 30 days
Force active if last modified <= 60 days
Force active if last modified <= 90 days
Force active if last modified <= 180 days
Force active if last modified <= 365 days

userActiveAge.title: Age
userActiveAge.description:
The age after which the AWS IAM user
is no longer considered active. If a create time is unavailable, the time Turbot discovered the resource is used.

The [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active)
control determines whether the resource is in active use, and if not, has
the ability to delete / cleanup the resource. When running an automated
compliance environment, it's common to end up with a wide range of alarms
that are difficult and time consuming to clear. The Active control brings
automated, well-defined control to this process.

The Active control checks the status of all defined Active policies for the
resource (`AWS > IAM > User > Active > *`),
raises an alarm, and takes the defined enforcement action. Each Active
sub-policy can calculate a status of active, inactive or skipped. Generally,
if the resource appears to be Active for any reason it will be considered Active.
**Note** the contrast with Approved, where if the resource appears to be Unapproved
for any reason it will be considered Unapproved.

See [Active](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/active) for more information.

userApproved.title: Approved
userApproved.description:
Determine the action to take when an AWS IAM user is not approved based on `AWS > IAM > User > Approved > *` policies.

The Approved control checks the status of the defined Approved sub-policies for the resource. If the resource is not approved according to any of these policies, this control raises an alarm and takes the defined enforcement action.

For any enforcement actions that specify `if new`, e.g., `Enforce: Delete unapproved if new`, this control will only take the enforcement actions for resources created within the last 60 minutes.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

userApprovedUsage.title: Usage
userApprovedUsage.description:
Determine whether the AWS IAM user is allowed to exist.

This policy will be evaluated by the Approved control. If an AWS IAM user is not approved, it will be subject to the action specified in the `AWS > IAM > User > Approved` policy.

See [Approved](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/approved) for more information.

userApprovedTurbot.title: Turbot
userApprovedTurbot.description: Determine whether IAM Policies that are defined and configured by Turbot (for example, from the Permissions stack or the Service Roles stack) will always be approved.

userPolicyAttachmentsApproved.title: Approved
userPolicyAttachmentsApproved.description:
Configure AWS IAM user policy attachments `Approved` checking. This policy
defines whether to verify the IAM user attached policies are approved
(per `Approved > Compiled Rules`), as well as the subsequent action to
take on unapproved items.
If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved attached policy
will be removed.

userPolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.title: Rules
userPolicyAttachmentsApprovedRules.description:
An [Object Control List (OCL)](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/reference/ocl) with a list of filter rules

Note that the Approved control does not operate directly from this policy,
but from the `Approved > Compiled Rules`.  The rules are processed in order,
and any built-in Turbot rules will appear first in the list of compiled rules.

userBoundary.title: Boundary
userBoundary.description:
Configure which boundary policy to apply to the IAM user .
This must be the name of an existing AWS IAM Boundary policy.
AWS Boundary Policies are used to enforce Turbot Guardrails for
enabling/disabling API Services and Regions.

If set to `Check or Enforce per AWS > Turbot > Permissions`,
the boundary will be enforced if Turbot > Permissions are enforced, checked
if Turbot > Permissions are  checked, and skipped if Turbot Permissions
are none or skip

enum: Check or Enforce per `AWS > Turbot > Permissions`

userCmdb.title: CMDB
userCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for the AWS IAM user into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.com/v5/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that resource type in the Turbot CMDB.
All policies and controls in Turbot are based around the resource, so usually the CMDB policy is set to **"Enforce: Enabled"**.

If set to Skip then all changes to the CMDB are paused - no new resources will be discovered, no updates will be made and deleted resources will not be removed.

To cleanup resources and stop tracking changes, set this policy to **"Enforce: Disabled"**.

roleInlinePolicyConfiguredPrecedence.description:
An ordered list of who is allowed to claim a resource.
A stack cannot claim a resource if it is already claimed by another
stack at a higher level of precedence.
roleInlinePolicyConfiguredPrecedence.defaultTemplate: {%- if $.defaultPrecedence | length == 0 %}[]{%- else %}{% for item in $.defaultPrecedence %}- '{{ item }}'{% endfor %}{% endif %}

roleInlinePolicyStatementsApproved.title: Approved
roleInlinePolicyStatementsApproved.description:
Configure IAM Policy Statements checking. This policy defines whether to verify the
policy statements are approved, as well as the subsequent action to take on unapproved
statements.
Rules for all Approved policies will be compiled in Approved > Compiled Rules
and then evaluated. If set to "Enforce: Delete unapproved", any unapproved statements
will be removed from the policy.

roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedRules.title: Rules
roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedRules.description:
An Object Control List (OCL) with a list of filter rules to approve or reject IAM role inline policy statements. Note that the Approved control does not operate directly from this policy, but from the Approved > Compiled Rules. The rules are processed in order, and any built-in Turbot rules will appear first in the list of compiled rules.
This is the last statement, so all unmatched items will be (approved/rejected) by this statement.

_Note_: Removing APPROVE * will reject all the unmatched rules.

roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedAdminA.title: Administrator Access
roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedAdminA.description: If set to "Disabled", IAM Role Inline Policy statements that allow any action ('*') on any resource ('*') will be unapproved.

roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedCompil.title: Compiled Rules
roleInlinePolicyStatementsApprovedCompil.description: A read-only Object Control List (OCL) to approved or reject inline policy statements for an IAM Role.  This policy is generated by Turbot based on the "Approved > *" policies.

instanceProfileCmdb.title: CMDB
instanceProfileCmdb.description:
Configure whether to record and synchronize details for AWS IAM instance profile(s) into the CMDB.

The [CMDB](https://turbot.cloud/docs/concepts/guardrails/cmdb) control is
responsible for populating and updating all the attributes for that
resource type in the Turbot CMDB.

Note that if CMDB is set to Skip for a resource, then it will not be added
to the CMDB, and no controls that target it will run.

instanceProfileConfigured.title: Configured
instanceProfileConfigured.description:
Determine how to configure this resource.

**Note**: If the resource is managed by another stack, then the Skip/Check/Enforce values here are ignored
and inherit from the stack that owns it

enum: Check: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
Enforce: Per Configured > Source (unless claimed by a stack)
